--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>
wrote:
> 
> I second Eric's suggestion: one usually needs to be
> able to create model 
> objects from the XML at some point, anyway. One of
> the great things about using 
> JUnit is that it encourages us to build equals(),
> hashCode() and toString() to 
> do useful things in our objects. How many times have
> you tried to debug 
> something and wished that the author had simply
> implemented toString() do tell 
> you something useful?
> 
> 
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> President, Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Let's write software that people understand.
> 

Yes, I've noticed this quite a bit lately myself. 
Running the unit tests, something fails, and I get
that stupid class description printed out.  So I go
make a toString() [after writing the test for it
first].  Same for equals() [instead of running through
and calling equals on each individual member of a
class].

-Eric
